quote: -- I knew my paper would be    controversial, but I had no idea    it was going to turn the entire    conference upside-down. Believe    me, Jake, panel discussions    are usually a lot    more civilized than that.
I don't know... they seemed polite   enough to me.

That was just a veneer.         My paper stepped on quite a few    toes. It's heresy to even    consider the possibility that    prion replication could be    inhibited by quantum resonance    effects.
Aren't you going to take notes?
Good idea...
According to the so called    "experts," it's all a matter of    amino acid re-sequencing and    disulfide shuffling -- quantum    dynamics has nothing to do with    it.
I have absolutely no idea what    he's talking about.
But how can that be? After all,    peptide bonds can be reconfigured    on a quantum level.

If I don't find a way     Now get this:  a few to get out of doing     months ago I was this article, my first     running a neural scan  writing assignment is     and noticed some  going to be my last     anomalous protein         readings. Do you follow so far?
Sort of...
Good. Because they're the key --   the protein anomalies.
Who cares about anomalies!

about things they can    They indicate a relate to: life and    correlative increase death, good and evil.    in prion replication. character: An outbreak ofone of two things --
quote: Cartalian fever would    either the peptide be perfect - the     bonds are unstable, brave doctor battles    or some other factor the deadly virus.     is causing the        mutations.
brave doctor battles    or some other factor the deadly virus.     is causing the        mutations.
mutations.
It's a distress call from the    Federation colony on Ajilon Prime.        They're under attack -- the    Klingons have landed troops.
So much for the cease-fire.
The main hospital's been    damaged... they're short on    doctors, running low on    supplies...
What are we waiting for? Let's    go.
It's risky. The hospital's only    fifty kilometers from the front    lines.
You put yourself into dangerous    situations all the time.
Maybe, but that's not the same as    putting you into one.
Don't worry about me.
You're too young to die.
I'm eighteen.
You know what I mean.       I've been on the station when it   was under attack plenty of times.   I can handle myself. I'm a Sisko.
Lives are at stake. Those people   need you.
I hope I don't regret this...
I can only imagine what your   father's going to say...
He'll understand.
I'll get you out of there as soon   as reinforcements arrive.
I wouldn't want you to miss the    deadline on your story.         Did they want a picture of me?
Anyway, about those quantum scans   I was telling you about --

(continuing in "Surgery Under Fire."    background)       Instead of scanning He smiles, looks down at the  each peptide bond, PADD.      it occurred to me       that I could scan  JAKE     for irregularities in Now we're talking...   the...
He smiles, looks down at the  each peptide bond, PADD.      it occurred to me       that I could scan  JAKE     for irregularities in Now we're talking...   the...
that I could scan  JAKE     for irregularities in Now we're talking...   the...
JAKE     for irregularities in Now we're talking...   the...
What is it?
The chief asked me to come up with    a decaffeinated raktajino for    Kira. I'm thinking of marketing    it.
Well... ?
Ugh... it's awful.
Give it a chance.
Let me taste.
Quark.
I did the best I could. The    removal of caffeine from beverages    has plagued bartenders and    restauranteurs for centuries; you    can't expect me to solve it    overnight.
I'm not paying for this.
So much for "Quark"-tajino...
I wanted to get her off caffeine,    not poison her.
You make me sound like some sort    of addict.
She only has maybe two raktajinos    a day.
I just don't want my son to be    born with a caffeine habit, that's    all.
You're being ridiculous.         Why does pregnancy always make men    hysterical?
Excuse me, this isn't the first    baby I've had.
Excuse me, Keiko carried Molly.
It's not up to you to tell Kira    what she can and can't do.
She is carrying his child, he    should have some say.
As the lessee, he does have    certain rights.        Back home, pregnancy is considered    a rental.
Rental?
Something wrong, Captain?
I just talked to Doctor Bashir.    He's on his way to Ajilon Prime to    answer a request for medical    assistance.
Jake's with him...
According to the latest reports,    Klingon ground troops have already    captured two settlements in the   northern hemisphere.
Half the colonists are still    trapped on the planet -- there are    no ships in the area to evacuate    them.
We're three days away, at best.
The Farragut will be there the day    after tomorrow. Bashir said he    and Jake would leave as soon as    relief teams are in place.
In that case they'll be home by    Thursday.        Doesn't leave you much time to    snoop through Jake's things.
Ready to beam down?

We can't leave the runabout in    orbit, not with the Klingons    around. Besides, the colonists    moved what was left of their    medical equipment underground when   the hospital was destroyed. The    rock-face contains magnesite...    there's no way to transport    through it.
Guess we'll have to find a place    to set down.
Looks like there's a clearing    about a kilometer from the main    settlement.
Jake... things could get a little    rough down there. They've got a    lot of wounded.
I'll be all right.
We've got more wounded coming in...    another hopper just landed.
I need that plasma!
Are you Bashir?
We got your distress call.
Resource said you were on your   way.
Watch it --
This is the last IP --
His pulse is thready, he must be   bleeding somewhere.
We're losing him!
Doctor --
Jump right in, standard triage.
Give him fifteen mils   inoprovaline.
What should I do?
Just try to stay out of the way.
Get this man into surgery!
The artery's severed --
His BP's bottomed out.
Oh-Two, three liters, run full   saline.
Somebody! This man needs help!
Help me! Somebody help me!
I've been hit...
Let me have a look.
Took a disruptor blast, real close --
Where's that blood plasma!
There's nothing we can do. He's   too far gone.
It doesn't look that bad --
I  was stepping over a Klingon,    thought he was dead. Caught me    right in the foot.
You people better get out of here    while you still can... the    Klingons -- there's no stopping    them...
This is a phaser burn.
What are you talking about?
(giving a hypo     injection)    ust sit tight and we'll get to    you as soon as we can.
I took, my phaser... and I... It's    not a phaser burn... It was a    Klingon...
You weren't there... you don't    know what it was like...

The Klingons had us pinned down...    we were done for, we all knew it.    Hendriks and Pajal got scared and    ran -- they ran. Then Sully got    hit in the leg and the medics    pulled him off the line -- all I    could think was I wish I was    him... So I...
I took my phaser... and I... Oh,   God... what'd I do to myself...   what'd I do... ?
Better find somewhere else to    sit...
No problem...
Triage... the sorting of the    wounded... forces decisions that --
(putting pen to paper    again)   Decisions that test what it means   to be a doctor.
Hey, you!
Give me a hand.        Come on!
This way --
Watch it!
Nice move...
Here you are, sir, a nice private    room with a view.         On three... one, two, three --
You can count -- you're hired.    Let's get you dressed.
Over here --
I want to try an aortal graft.
All right, there's an extra    surgical table in the back.
He's dead...
Come on... let's get him out of    here...
Party's over...
(feigning     disappointment)    So soon?
And we were just starting to have    fun...
Since you two aren't busy, would    you mind carrying me to the    nearest replicator so I can get    something to eat?
You wanted to see me, Captain?
I heard you took a little trip to    the Infirmary.
I'll be fine.
The only permanent damage was to    my pride.
What happened?
Quark asked me to keep an eye on    two Yridians he thought were    cheating at dabo. Turned out he    was right.

I could see from the second level    that one of them was using a    miniature gravimetric scanner to    predict where the ball would land    on the wheel, then signaling the    information to his partner.
Ingenious.  Go on.
I started down the stairs to make    the arrest and one of them saw me.    When they bolted, I... pursued.    But in the rush I got a little    carried away and I...
You jumped off the stairs.
I was planning to change form in    mid-air and become a Tarkalean    condor.
That would've been impressive.
I thought so.
It's an understandable mistake.    You were a changeling a lot longer    than you've been a solid.
Solid... I wonder why my people    use that term -- humanoid bodies    are so fragile.
Yes, they are. And it's a    dangerous universe out there.
You're worried about Jake.
I'm sure Doctor Bashir is looking    out for him.
Seems just yesterday he was five   years old... clinging to me   because held scraped his knee and   I was the only one in the world   who could make it better.

I remember getting up sometimes in    the middle of the night and    slipping into his room just to    make sure he was all right... I'd    sit there and watch him sleep...    and think to myself that no matter    what, I'd never let anything bad    happen to this child.
Now he's a sector away, in the    middle of a war zone, and there's    nothing I can do to protect him.
Try not to worry, Captain. It's    not going to do you or Jake any    good.
Can't help it, comes with the    territory.
But Jake is eighteen years old.         Does your father still worry about    you?
All the time.
I never realized how stressful it    is to be a parent. I have to say,    I don't think it's for me.
That's your choice.         But you don't know what you're    missing.
Yes.
We just got word -- the Klingons    destroyed the Farragut near the    Lembatta cluster.
What about Ajilon Prime, without    reinforcements --
Dax, you're with me. We'll leave    as soon as the Defiant's ready.
Here you go...
Thanks.
So how're you holding up?
Okay.
You handled yourself well today.    I'm impressed.
I'm starved.
(picking up knife and     fork)   Think I'll start with a lateral   incision across the thigh joint...
His first day?
Yeah.
Pass the salt.
How do you feel?
Fresh air did me good...
You remember that ensign, the one   who shot himself?
How could I forget something like   that?
What's going to happen to him?
He'll probably be court martialed.
He said that some of the people in    his squad got scared and ran.
It happens.
But they're Starfleet -- they've    passed psych-tests, spent hundreds    of hours in battle simulations.
Simulations can't prepare you for    the real thing. Nothing can.
Some people say you don't know    what you're really made of until    you've been in battle...

(throwing an arm around     Jake's shoulder)    Believe me, Jake, there are plenty    of situations in life that test a    person's character -- thankfully,    most of them don't involve death    and destruction...
Doctor Kalandra's looking for you.    Something about that aortal graft    you did.
Thanks.        See you later.
How is he?
The graft's holding -- blood    throughput is almost a hundred    percent.        Nice job.
Thanks.    (returning the    compliment)   You've got a good team here. My   O.R. Nurse was sharp as they   come.
We do the best we can, considering    the circumstances.
So are things going any better for    us? Last I heard Starfleet had    pulled out of the Arcanis sector.
The fleet's regrouping to launch    a counterattack.
Do you have any idea what ships    are involved? We don't get much    news down here, the Klingons have    been jamming subspace traffic.
I think the Rutledge and the    Tecumseh are heading things up.
The Tecumseh...        My husband's the science officer.
Captain Raymond's one of the best    there is... he saw the Tecumseh    through the Cardassian wars -- I    don't think he's planning to lose    her now.
No, I don't suppose he is.
Doctor, we've prepped that spinal    trauma, they're ready for you in    surgery.
I'll be right there.
They're keeping you busy.
It helps keep my mind off things.
Good to see you've got your    appetite back.
I've got a pretty strong    stomach...       ... most of the time.
Don't worry about it. Same thing    happened to me my first day.
Know what I heard?        That ship Starfleet sent, the    Farragut? The Klingons    intercepted it.
Starfleet'll send another one,    won't they?

It won't get here for days. In    the meantime we're looking at a    ground war, which is just what the    Klingons want. According to a    lieutenant I talked to, they've    got so many transport scramblers    on-line we can't beam troops    anywhere.
What about using hoppers?
He said the Klingons have been    shooting them out of the sky left    and right. Unless something    changes, he figures the    Klingons'll capture the settlement    the day after tomorrow.
Did you see all the bat'leth    wounds today?
(off Jake's nod   When Klingons get mad, they forget    about their disruptors, go hand-to-   hand.        If you ask me, they're looking to    get even for what happened on    Ganalda Four.
What happened?
They had to retreat -- Klingons    hate that.
At least we don't have to worry    about them in here.

Don't be so sure. Medical    personnel are fair game as far as    Klingons are concerned. They'll    even kill wounded, right in their    beds -- they think they're giving    them an honorable death, or    something.
So... how'd you wind up here?
I, uh... I'm writing an article    about Doctor Bashir.
You're a journalist?

I wonder if Kirby    Not exactly. knew that the whole time we were talking,    KIRBY all I could think    What does that mean? about was how close the Klingons were.    JAKE       I write stories mostly,       you know, fiction.
you know, fiction.

-- He didn't seem that worried, no    one else seems to be losing sleep    over it, so why's it the only    thing I can think about? I've    been on the station when it was    under attack plenty of times...    but somehow the danger never   seemed as real as it does here.
scene: 25   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - LATER

quote: Maybe it's because I spent all day    seeing firsthand what the    Klingons are capable of... or    maybe it's because for the first    time in my life, my father's not    here to protect me.
scene: 25   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - LATER

quote: What was that?
scene: 25   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - LATER

quote: The Klingons -- they must've taken    out the reactor...
scene: 25   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - LATER

quote: He's fibrillating!
Kidney failure, she's going into    renal shock --
If we don't get power back soon    we'll lose half the ward.
I just talked to Resource. It's    going to be at least three hours    before we have power again.
There must be some portable    generators we could use.
They're using them to keep the    shields up around the settlement.
The runabout... there's a portable    generator on the runabout.
Where is it?
About a kilometer south of here.        I'll need help carrying it.
You won't be able to beam through    the shields, you'll have to take    the east tunnel.
It lets out beyond the perimeter.   I'll show you.
We set down just beyond that   bridge.
Looks familiar...
Get down!
Stay close... keep your head    low.
No matter what happens, one of us    has got to get that generator.
Come on!
Jake!
Medkit...
Over there...
Now.
Hypo...
Sit me up.
Do it. I'm not going to die with    my face in the dirt.
(getting a grip on     himself)   Okay...
How's your head?
Hurts.
You're lucky I didn't kill you -    thought you were a Klingon. Have    you seen any?
What?
Klingons -- are there any patrols    around?
What about Starfleet?
No one.
Just you and me then.        What the hell are you doing out    here? Why'd you leave the    settlement?
I was outside when the shelling    started. I guess I got lost    trying to find cover.
Lucky me. I could use the    company.
Here... water.
What about you?
Go ahead.
Thanks.
It probably would've leaked out of    me anyway...
Don't let me fall over. I want to    go out looking up at the sky, not    the ground, all right?
Don't worry.
You didn't see a crashed hopper    around here, did you?
No.
They made it.
Who?

My platoon. The Klingons had us    pinned down. We couldn't beam out    because they had a transport    scrambler running... so we called    for a hopper. As soon as it set    down, the Klingons came at us.    Our C.O. ordered me and Brice to    lay down cover so the squad could    get up the ramp.    (shaking his head as he    remembers)   By the time Brice got in, the   Klingons were practically on top   of us. The hopper was taking such   a pounding, I didn't think it   would make it off the ground.
You stayed behind on purpose, so    they could get away.
The hypo... where is it?
It's empty...
Figures...
I'm going to get you out of here.
I'll make a stretcher...
With what?
Then I'll carry you.
Kid, you try picking me up, and my    guts'll wind up all over your    shoes.
But I've got to do something, I've    got to try.
Forget it.
But I have to. That way this'll    all make sense. I ran for a    reason -- so I could find you and    bring you back and save your life.
Ran -- ?

From the explosions -- we had to    get to the runabout, for the    generator, but then the shelling    started and I couldn't see Doctor    Bashir and the explosions kept    getting closer and I had to get    out of there so I ran, I ran and    I kept running until I found you.
The doctor -- you left him.
It was a mistake.
That's what you call it.
I didn't mean for it to happen.
And now you think that bringing me    back is going to make everything    all right.
Sorry, kid.       Life doesn't work that way.
Benjamin --
Be right out...
What've you been doing in there    for three hours?
Oh, I was just tweaking the    pattern buffers in the replicator    systems.
Great, I always thought the coffee    could be a little hotter.
Just trying to keep busy.
Is it helping?
Not really.
I wish there was something I could    do, some way I could promise you    that everything is going to be    okay.
But you can't. No one can.

I know what it's like to worry    about a child. Raifi put Tobin    through hell -- and when Neema was    six, she came down with Regulan    fever. Audrid spent two weeks in    the hospital with her, never left    her side. It was hundreds of    years ago, and I still remember    how helpless I felt. I read her    all seventeen volumes of Caster's    Down the River Light, even though    I knew she couldn't hear me. It    made me feel like I was doing    something, that we were still    connected. It wasn't until much    later that I realized I was doing    it as much for me as for her.
To keep busy.
So how did it turn out, with    Neema?
She pulled through.
I was hoping you were going to say    that. If that story had an    unhappy ending, I never would've    forgiven you.
Of course, by the time she was    twenty-one, Neema wouldn't even    speak to me.
For how long?
About eight years.
Do me a favor, tell me about it    some other time. Right now, all    I care about is seeing Jake again.
You will -- tomorrow, when we get    to Ajilon Prime.
You know, Ben... coffee can never    be too hot. Are you sure you got    the Replicator buffers synchronized?
You want to check for yourself?
I think I will. Can I borrow your    decoupler?
Get your own. I'm going to go    check the sonic shower relays.
Good idea.
Jake!
We thought you were... this is    great.
What happened?
I got knocked out when we were    trying to get to the runabout.    Did Doctor Bashir make it back all    right?
He's in IC for the night, plasma    burns on his arm and shoulder. I    don't know how he managed it, but    he carried the generator back here    by himself.

We went looking for you when the    shelling stopped. There was    hardly anything left of the    runabout... the whole place was    nothing but bomb craters and    smoke. We pretty much gave up    hope.
I must've wandered off in the    wrong direction when I came to.
You're lucky you didn't get picked    up by the Klingons. Word is,    they're massing to attack the    compound.
You want to see him?
I should probably let him rest.
He's awake, I was just in there.
Go ahead, he'll be glad to see    you're okay.
Jake... ?
Thank God...
I thought you'd been killed. Once    the shelling stopped and I    couldn't find you, I assumed the    worst.
I'm sorry.
It's all right.
No, it's not. I never should've    brought you here in the first place.        Now we're stuck here, the Klingons    are massing to attack -- what was    I thinking!
Forget it, okay! What's done is    done.
I couldn't stand hearing him    apologize to me like that... not    after what I'd done...
All right, you two, visiting hours    re over.       Let me have a look at that.
I keep turning it over in my   head...

The shelling, losing sight of    Bashir, running... and I keep    trying to make sense of it all, to   justify what I did. But when it    comes down to it, there's only one    explanation. I'm a coward.
scene: 47   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - NIGHT

quote: Part of me wishes Bashir had seen    me run away and told everyone the    truth. They deserve to know what    I am... they should know they    can't count on me... that if the    Klingons attack, I'll run and hide    just like I did before...
scene: 47   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - NIGHT

quote: Jake, take this to the patient in    G-four, would you?
Sure.
Here you go...
One of the nurses asked me to    bring you this.
Maybe I'll get a job as a cutter --    could be interesting work.
What's a cutter?
You know, on a mining team.    They're the guys who split the    asteroids up with phasers so the    excavators can get at what's    inside.
You've got to have good aim... and    no matter what else you can say    about me, you can't say I don't    have good aim.
If I hadn't hit my foot just    right, I would've taken my whole    leg off.

It's funny... one minute your    life's moving along just the way    you always figured it would, the    next... you do something that    changes everything, that makes you   realize you're not who you thought    you were.
At the Academy, I did really well    in the battle simulations - never   had any problems -- but when    you're out there, live shells    detonating all around you, it's a    whole different thing.
All you can think about is getting    away from the explosions...
Yeah. That's pretty much it.
You know something... you're    first person I've talked to since    I got here who hasn't made me feel    like I'm taking up valuable bed    space.
The way everyone looks at me... I    can't stand it. After the court    martial, I'm going to sign up for    the next mining expedition to the    Gamma Quadrant.
Maybe there won't be a court    martial.
You're right, none of us may get    out of here alive.
No, I mean -- Starfleet could    decide to send you to counseling    instead.
I won't go.
I don't deserve to be in   Starfleet. Therapy won't change    what I did. Nothing can.
I just wish I'd aimed that phaser    a little higher...
I saw the report on Doctor    Kalandra's desk. According to   Resource, it's only a matter of    time before the Klingons reach the    compound.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: I guess that means I have to    decide.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Decide what?
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Whether I'd rather get hacked to    bits, or blasted by a disruptor.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Disruptor, no doubt about it --    every molecule in your body    vaporized in a flash. No time to    feel pain.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Don't be so sure about that. Some    people think it's like being    boiled alive.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Decapitation has its virtues. A    clean blow with a nice, sharp    bat'leth.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Your brain doesn't die for five,    ten seconds at least...
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: In theory, your headless corpse    could be the last thing you see.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: You're so negative.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: I'm just telling you what I've    heard.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: What do you think, Jake?
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: I think it's not funny.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Of course not.    (reaching toward Jake to     mime the action)    There's nothing funny about having    your throat slit by --
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Cut it out!
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: You all think this is some big    joke. It's not. People are    dying!
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: I was just kidding.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: It's all so stupid. This whole    stupid war is such a waste. In    ten years, no one's going to    remember what anyone did here.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Jake --
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Maybe you saved a hopper full of    people, maybe you shot yourself in    the foot -- no one's going to   remember.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Jake.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: Come on. Let's take a walk.
scene: 49   INT. CAVERN - STAFF BUNK ROOM - DAY

quote: I'm sorry.
Look, I know you're scared -- we    all are.
No... yes, it's not that -- I...
What, Jake -- what is it?
I just didn't think what they were    saying was funny...
Come on. That's not what set you    off. Something's eating at you,   I can see it.
I don't know what you're talking    about.
Ever since you came back you've    been walking around here looking    miserable.
Leave me alone.
Jake --
Leave me alone!
All right. If that's what you    want. But you know where to find    me if you want to talk...
Are they inside    What's going on? the compound?
Everyone listen.   What are we going to do?
We're evacuating.
We're going to take the patients    out the north tunnel to the    surface. A hopper is going to    take us down the peninsula to the    base at Tananda Bay.
That tunnel is almost two    kilometers long... we've got over    seventy patients to move -- you    know how long that's going to    take?
Resource is sending a security    detail to defend the hospital and    give us enough time to evacuate.
We can do this.
We have to stay calm. Focus on    your job. Those people in there    need us.
Let's move.
This way... keep moving.
Give me a hand --
Is that it -- two guards?
The rest must be out defending the   perimeter.
Great, one's leaving.
We're going someplace safe, all   right?
They're coming!
Move.
Come on, let's go!
Anyone left back there?
No --
Get down!
Jake, looks who's here --

scene: 78   INT. CAVERN - MAIN WARD - JAKES POV

quote: What happened?

quote: Admittedly, the timing could have    been a little better, but...
scene: 78   INT. CAVERN - MAIN WARD - JAKES POV

quote: He seems to be all right.
scene: 78   INT. CAVERN - MAIN WARD - JAKES POV

quote: Sealing the entrance way was a    risky thing to do. You almost    brought the whole ceiling down on    yourself.
scene: 78   INT. CAVERN - MAIN WARD - JAKES POV

quote: Still, we never would've gotten    all the patients out if he hadn't    done it.        You're a hero.
scene: 78   INT. CAVERN - MAIN WARD - JAKES POV

quote: More than anything, I wanted to    believe what he was saying...
scene: 78   INT. CAVERN - MAIN WARD - JAKES POV

quote: But the truth is, I was just as    scared in that hospital as I'd    been when we went for the    generator...
(continuing   So scared, that all I could think    about was doing whatever it took    to stay alive...
Once that meant running away, and    once it meant picking up a    phaser...

The battle of Ajilon Prime will   probably be remembered as a   pointless skirmish, but I'll   always remember it as something   more -- as the place I learned   that the line between courage and   cowardice is a lot thinner than   most people believe...
So what do you think... ?
Anyone who's been in battle would    recognize himself in this... but    most of us wouldn't care to admit    it.
It takes courage to look inside    yourself... and even more courage    to write about it for other people   to see.
I'm proud of you, son...
